title: Brecon Bike & Hike
tagline: BikePark Wales meets mountain summits - the ultimate South Wales adventure weekend
highlights: Pen y Fan summit (886m) - highest peak in South Wales
suitableFor: Experienced mountain bikers and hikers with good fitness who enjoy challenging trails and varied terrain. Confident navigating in potentially exposed conditions.
notSuitableFor: Beginner cyclists or hikers, those with limited fitness, or anyone uncomfortable with heights or changeable weather conditions. Not ideal for families with young children.
packingEssentials: Hiking boots with good ankle support
Navigation tools (OS map OL12, compass, GPS)
Warm layers (summit temperature can be 10°C lower)

stops.title: BikePark Wales - Uplift Day
stops.description: Hit the UK's premier purpose-built mountain bike park. 40+ trails from green (beginner) to pro (terrifying). Uplift service takes you to the top, you ride down - repeat all day. Trails include flowing berms, jumps, rock gardens, and technical descents. Cafe, shop, and bike wash on site.
stops.costNote: Day uplift pass. Weekend prices higher.

trailRecommendations.beginner: Badgers Run (green) - flowing berms, pump track warm-up
trailRecommendations.intermediate: Willy Waver (blue) - swooping turns, small jumps
trailRecommendations.advanced: Dai Hard (red) - technical rock gardens, drops
trailRecommendations.expert: Rim Dinger (black) - steep chutes, gnarly rocks

stops.insiderTip: Arrive before 9am opening to get first uplift and fresh trails. Bring knee pads - even reds have rocky sections. The cafe burgers are excellent post-ride fuel. Book uplift online in advance - walk-ups sometimes available but not guaranteed.

wetAlt.title: BikePark runs in rain!
wetAlt.description: Trails are purpose-built and drain well. Some riders prefer wet conditions - less dust, more grip. Only closed in extreme weather. Pack waterproofs and embrace it.

budgetAlt.title: Taff Trail Cycling
budgetAlt.description: Ride the Taff Trail - 55 miles from Cardiff Bay to Brecon. Join at Merthyr for the scenic valley section. Free!

stops.title: BikePark Wales Cafe
stops.description: Refuel at the on-site cafe with burgers, wraps, and excellent coffee. Log burner for cold days, outdoor deck for sunny ones. Filled with muddy, happy bikers.

alternative.title: Nant Ddu Lodge
alternative.description: Country pub en route to the Beacons. Good food and real ales.

stops.title: The Roost Merthyr Tydfil
stops.description: Purpose-built accommodation near BikePark Wales. Self-catering with secure bike storage, drying room, and jet wash. Family and dog-friendly. Perfect bikers' base.
stops.insiderTip: Book the whole place if you're a group - works out great value. The drying room is essential if you've been riding in Welsh rain.

budgetAlt.title: YHA Brecon Beacons
budgetAlt.description: Modern eco-hostel in the heart of the Beacons. Dorms and private rooms. Good communal areas.

premiumAlt.title: Llangoed Hall
premiumAlt.description: Stunning country house hotel with spa. Proper treat after a day of riding.

stops.title: Pen y Fan Summit Hike
stops.description: Tackle the highest peak in South Wales (886m) via the classic Storey Arms route. The 6-mile round trip takes 3-4 hours. Views from the summit stretch to Snowdonia, the Bristol Channel, and beyond on clear days. The twin peaks of Corn Du and Pen y Fan are iconic.
stops.costNote: Free hike, parking £5 at Storey Arms
stops.travelToNext: On foot - return to car park
stops.insiderTip: Start EARLY (before 7am) to beat the crowds and get parking. The Storey Arms car park fills by 9am on sunny weekends. Alternative: use the smaller car park at Pont ar Daf for a gentler approach. Check MWIS for weather - summit can be wild when valley is calm.

wetAlt.title: Dan yr Ogof Show Caves
wetAlt.description: Explore Britain's largest showcase caves - underground waterfalls, formations, and a dinosaur park. Family-friendly all-weather attraction.

budgetAlt.title: Corn Du only
budgetAlt.description: If time or energy is limited, hike to Corn Du (873m) - almost as high as Pen y Fan with fewer crowds. Turn back before the final push to Pen y Fan.

stops.title: The Tai'r Bull (Libanus)
stops.description: Traditional village pub just down from the Beacons. Hearty Welsh food, real ales, and a warm welcome for muddy hikers. Large portions ideal post-summit.

alternative.title: Storey Arms Cafe (seasonal)
alternative.description: Basic refreshments at the car park. Can be closed off-season.

budgetAlt.title: Picnic at the summit
budgetAlt.description: Pack lunch and enjoy it on top of Pen y Fan (weather permitting). Nothing beats a sarnie with a view.

stops.title: Four Falls Trail (Waterfall Country)
stops.description: Walk the famous Four Falls Trail in Waterfall Country. The 5-mile circular route takes you past four stunning waterfalls including Sgwd yr Eira where you can walk behind the water. Magical forest setting, dramatic gorges, and ancient woodland.
stops.costNote: Free walk, parking £5-7 at Pontneddfechan or Cwm Porth

waterfalls.name: Sgwd yr Eira
waterfalls.note: Walk behind the curtain of water!

stops.insiderTip: Wear shoes with grip - the paths are slippery, especially near the falls. Sgwd yr Eira (Fall of Snow) is the highlight - you can walk along a rocky ledge behind the waterfall. The paths can be muddy after rain but that makes the waterfalls more impressive.

wetAlt.title: Waterfalls are BETTER in rain!
wetAlt.description: Waterfall Country is called that for a reason. After rain, the falls are at their most dramatic. Bring waterproofs and embrace the moisture.

budgetAlt.title: Short circuit to Sgwd yr Eira only
budgetAlt.description: If tired from Pen y Fan, walk the shorter route from Cwm Porth to just Sgwd yr Eira (2 miles round trip). Still magical.

stops.title: YHA Brecon Beacons
stops.description: Modern eco-hostel in the Usk Valley. Private rooms and dorms, self-catering kitchen, and stunning valley views. Sustainable building with green credentials. Good base for day 3.
stops.insiderTip: The common room has huge windows overlooking the valley. Book a private room with valley view if you want to wake up to something special.

budgetAlt.title: Camping at Cwm Porth
budgetAlt.description: Basic campsite in Waterfall Country. Fall asleep to the sound of the river.

stops.title: Gorge Walking Adventure
stops.description: Scramble through a spectacular river gorge, climbing waterfalls, jumping into plunge pools, and sliding down natural water chutes. All equipment provided including wetsuit, helmet, and buoyancy aid. A wild and wet finale to your weekend.
stops.insiderTip: Gorge walking is actually MORE fun after rain - bigger waterfalls, fuller pools. Sessions rarely cancelled unless water levels are dangerous. Bring an old pair of trainers that can get soaked.

wetAlt.title: Still go gorge walking!
wetAlt.description: You're getting wet anyway! Gorge walking in the rain is brilliant - you barely notice because you're already soaked. Trust the experience.

budgetAlt.title: DIY Waterfall Plunge Pool
budgetAlt.description: Some plunge pools below waterfalls are accessible for wild swimming (e.g., Sgwd Gwladus). Only for confident swimmers who know the risks. Free but requires research and caution.

stops.title: The Angel Hotel (Abergavenny)
stops.description: Treat yourself to lunch at this acclaimed gastro-pub in Abergavenny - the food capital of Wales. Local produce, excellent cooking, and a reward for a weekend of adventure.

alternative.title: The Walnut Tree
alternative.description: Michelin-starred restaurant nearby for a real blow-out. Book weeks ahead.

budgetAlt.title: Market Hall Abergavenny
budgetAlt.description: The covered market has excellent delis, bakers, and a cafe. Great for a cheaper but quality lunch.

standard.notes: Based on 2 adults, hostel/bunkhouse, all activities, bring own bike

budget.notes: Camping, one day BikePark, packed lunches, DIY alternatives

premium.notes: Country hotel, bike hire, coaching, restaurant meals

knowBeforeYouGo.weather: The Brecon Beacons are known for unpredictable weather - 2,000mm of rain per year! Always pack full waterproofs even on sunny forecasts. Mountain weather can change in minutes. BikePark Wales trails are all-weather but can be muddy.
knowBeforeYouGo.traffic: The A470 can be congested on summer weekends, especially heading to Cardiff. Parking at Pen y Fan (Storey Arms) fills by 9am on sunny weekends - arrive early or use alternatives. Waterfall Country parking is limited - arrive early.
knowBeforeYouGo.booking: BikePark Wales uplift passes should be booked in advance online, especially for weekends and school holidays. Gorge walking needs 48+ hours notice. Bike hire is limited - book well ahead.
knowBeforeYouGo.fitness: This itinerary is demanding. BikePark Wales requires good bike handling skills and fitness for repeated runs. Pen y Fan is a proper mountain hike with 600m+ elevation gain. Gorge walking needs swimming ability and some scrambling. Be honest about your fitness.
knowBeforeYouGo.bikeTransport: If bringing your own bike, ensure you have a suitable rack or van. BikePark has bike wash facilities. If hiring, book well in advance as stock is limited, especially full-suspension bikes.
knowBeforeYouGo.emergencies: Mountain rescue covers the Brecon Beacons. Mobile signal is patchy on summits and in valleys. Let someone know your plans. The national park has mountain weather stations - check before heading out.

addDay.title: Add Caving at Dan yr Ogof
addDay.description: Explore underground cave systems with a guided adventure trip. Go beyond the show caves into real caving passages.

alternative.title: Second BikePark Day
alternative.description: Skip the waterfalls and add another day at BikePark Wales. Progress from blue to red trails or try black runs.
